questions.text: Which of the following is the definition of $x$ divides $y$ (notation: $x \mid y$)?
questions.explanation: By definition, $x$ divides $y$ if there exists an integer $k$ such that $y = xk$. Be careful not to mix up $x$ and $y$!

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.explanation:
Remember that $a$ divides $b$ if $b = ak$ for some integer $k$.
• $5$ divides $0$ is true because $0 = 5 \cdot 0$.
• $12$ does not divide $4$ (the order matters).

questions.text: On a $12$-hour clock, what time is it $5$ hours after $9$ o'clock?
questions.explanation: $9 + 5 = 14$. Since clocks wrap around every $12$ hours, we subtract $12$ to get $14 - 12 = 2$.

questions.text: How do we express the clock calculation $9 + 5 = 2$ in modular arithmetic notation?
questions.explanation: We say that $14$ is congruent to $2$ modulo $12$. This is written as $14 \equiv 2 \pmod{12}$.

We divide $17$ by $5$: $17 = 3 \cdot 5 + 2$. The remainder is $2$.
(Note: $3$ is the quotient.)

questions.text: If $x \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$, which of the following could be a value of $x$?
questions.explanation:
We are looking for a number of the form $4k+1$.
$9 = 2 \cdot 4 + 1$, so it fits.

questions.text: Which of the following represents all integer solutions to $2x \equiv 2 \pmod 4$?
questions.explanation:
We cannot simply divide by 2 because $\gcd(2,4) \neq 1$.
$2x = 2 + 4k \implies 2x$ is $2, 6, 10, 14 \dots$
Dividing by 2 gives $x = 1, 3, 5, 7 \dots$, so $x \equiv 1$ or $3 \pmod 4$.

questions.text: What is the value of $\gcd(n, n+2)$ for any positive integer $n$?
questions.explanation: By the Euclidean algorithm, $\gcd(n, n+2) = \gcd(n, 2)$. If $n$ is even, this is $2$. If $n$ is odd, this is $1$.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about modular congruence is FALSE?
choices: If $a \equiv b \pmod n$, then $a^2 \equiv b^2 \pmod n$.
If $a^2 \equiv b^2 \pmod n$, then $a \equiv b \pmod n$.
If $a \equiv b \pmod n$, then $a + c \equiv b + c \pmod n$.
questions.explanation: Counterexample: Let $n=5$. Then $2^2 = 4$ and $3^2 = 9 \equiv 4$. So $2^2 \equiv 3^2 \pmod 5$, but $2 \not\equiv 3 \pmod 5$.
